Chapter 8, Part 4: The Chapter on Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha
At that time, Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

The practices of the buddhas are inconceivable, and the dharmas that bodhisattvas should practice are also immeasurable. Therefore, these practices cannot be accomplished with a small vow, cannot be accomplished with a few words, and cannot be accomplished with the path of the Lesser Vehicle.
Excellent!
World-Honored One!

I only pray that you will explain the great vow adornments and the path adornments of the bodhisattvas. Because the bodhisattvas' great vow adornments and path adornments enable them to ride the Great Vehicle and practice the true, supreme supramundane path, and thus attain the unsurpassed Great Vehicle of the world-transcending, and accomplish all the great wisdom of spontaneity.
Although they have not yet attained omniscience, they are able to perform buddha-works and benefit all.
The Buddha told Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha:
Good man!
Listen carefully, listen carefully!
Think about it well.
I will explain to you the great vows, the vehicle, and the path that adorn the bodhisattvas.
Yes, World-Honored One!
We joyfully wish to hear it.
The Buddha said:
Good men!
Bodhisattvas have twenty adornments with which to adorn themselves. Having adorned themselves, they are able to ride the Great Vehicle.
What are the twenty?
Good men!

If there are bodhisattvas who ultimately give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, they will give rise to the most supreme great compassion for all sentient beings, give rise to the mind of benefiting sentient beings, and having the mind of benefiting sentient beings, they will be able to adorn the unsurpassed great vow.
What is meant by the adornment of the great vow?ğŸ”½It is the adornment of the great vow to deliver those who are not yet delivered, because one rides in the great ship.
It is the adornment of the great vow to liberate those who are not yet liberated, because one frees them from false and inverted [views].
The great vow of adornment for those who are not yet at peace is to establish them on the fearless path.
The great vow of adornment for those who have not yet attained nirvana is to enable them to abandon the heavy burden of the five aggregates.
The great vow of adornment for always diligently providing for sentient beings is to be diligent and not lazy.
The great vow of adornment for not abandoning immeasurable birth and death is to not become weary.
The great vow of adornment for delighting all buddhas is to make offerings and pay homage to them in person.
The great vow of adornment for upholding all buddha-dharmas is to not cut off the lineage of the Three Jewels.
The great vow of adornment for upholding all that is heard and not forgetting it is to attain dhÄraá¹‡Ä«.
The great vow of adornment for skillfully expounding the Dharma and delighting all sentient beings is to attain eloquence.
The great vow of adornment for gathering immeasurable merit and virtue is to accomplish the major and minor marks.
To delight and please all good and wise advisors, to be firmly established in great vows and adornments, and to make one's practices solid.
To restrain a scattered mind, to be firmly established in great vows, and to give rise to various dhyanas, liberations, and samadhis.
To be in a place of solitude and abandon one's body and life, to be firmly established in great vows, and to attain the six spiritual powers.
To wish to roar the lion's roar without fear, to be firmly established in great vows, and to directly attain the Dharma of no-self.
To wish to reach all worlds, to be firmly established in great vows, and to wish to know that all dharmas are like illusions, dreams, and shadows.
To universally illuminate and adorn all worlds, to be firmly established in great vows, and to accomplish the power of upholding pure precepts.
To accomplish the Tathagata's ten powers, to be firmly established in great vows, and to fulfill the perfections.
To attain the four kinds of fearlessness, to be firmly established in great vows, and to practice as taught.

In order to attain the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha, one makes great vows to adorn oneself, and in accordance with what one has heard, the dharmas of the bodhisattva stage are free from conceptual proliferation.
Good man!
These are the twenty great vows of adornment of all bodhisattvas. By the power of these adornments, one is able to ride in the Great Vehicle.
Because of the power of adorning oneself in this way, bodhisattvas sever the causes and conditions of the three evil destinies. This is called adornment.
Being replete with goodness and being protected and upheld by the buddhas, this is called adornment.
Being able to be reborn wherever one wishes, this is called adornment.
Abandoning all wombs and being able to be reborn miraculously in the presence of the buddhas, this is called adornment.
Being able to practice unobstructed physical, verbal, and mental actions, this is called adornment.
Dwelling in heedfulness and being respected by the devas and humans, this is called adornment.
Being well-versed in the three gates of liberation but not realizing the ultimate truth, this is called adornment.
All dharmas are without self, yet still do not abandon the great vow adornment, this is called adornment.
This is called the bodhisattva's complete great vow adornment.
What is called adorning the bodhisattva vehicle?
Good man!

The vehicle is immeasurable, because it has no bounds, it is all-pervading like space, because it broadly accommodates all beings, it is not shared with Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, therefore it is called the great vehicle.
Furthermore, the vehicle takes the four means of conversion as its wheel, takes the true and pure ten wholesome
actions as its spokes, takes the pure merit and virtue provisions as its hub, takes the firm, sincere, and ultimate
as its axle and nails, takes the good accomplishment of various meditations, liberations, and samÄdhis as its yoke, takes the
four immeasurables as its good taming, takes the good spiritual friends as its charioteer, takes knowing the time and non-time
Using impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self as the sound of the whip, using the seven factors of enlightenment
as the reins, using the purification of the five faculties as the bridle, using vast, upright, and straight great
compassion as the banner, using the four right efforts as the net, using the four establishments of mindfulness as the steady pace,
using the four bases of supernatural power as the swift progress, using the five powers as the mirror for examining the array, using the eightfold noble path
as the straight path, and using the unobstructed wisdom-illumination of all sentient beings as the canopy.
Using the six pÄramitÄs without abiding to turn towards sarvajÃ±a, using the unequaled four noble truths to reach the other shore, this is the great vehicle.

This vehicle is accepted by all Buddhas, observed by Sravakas and Pratyekabuddhas, ridden by all Bodhisattvas, to be respectfully bowed to by Shakra, Brahma, and the World Protectors, to be made offerings to by all sentient beings, to be praised by all those with wisdom, to be taken refuge in by all worlds, to be not lightly disparaged by any enemies, to be not destroyed by any demons, to be not measured by any non-Buddhists, and to be not competed with by any worldly wisdom.
This vehicle is supreme and cannot be stopped by anyone, guarded by all sages and saints, because this vehicle can reach all Buddha lands according to one's wishes.
This vehicle is universally illuminating, because it can emit a net of light.
This vehicle has great fame, because it can produce the Dharma gate.ğŸ”½This vehicle is strong, because one's resolve does not retreat.ğŸ”½This vehicle is firm, because one is not lax.
This vehicle abides correctly, because it is unshakable.
This vehicle is fully equipped with all things and can fulfill all wishes.
Good man!
This is called the great adornment of the great vows of the Mahayana.

The bodhisattva rides this vehicle, and having ridden this vehicle, he is able to go from one stage to another stage, which is its adornment. He is able to abandon the faults of all stages, which is its adornment. He is able to abandon all demonic activities, which is its adornment. He is able to transform and liberate sentient beings, which is its adornment. He is able to purify the Buddha-lands, which is its adornment. He is able to manifest the spiritual transformations of the bodhisattvas, which is its adornment. He is able to cross over the great famine of birth and death, which is its adornment. He is able to enter the realm of the Tathagata's activity, which is its adornment.
Good man!
What is the bodhisattva's adorned path?
Good man!
The bodhisattva, having already adorned the great vehicle with the great vows, abandons all wrong paths, and having abandoned all wrong paths, he enters the true correct path and reaches sarvajÃ±a.
What is the correct path?

Namely, in order not to abandon good dharmas, one practices great desire; in order not to regress from the path of enlightenment, one diligently cultivates vigor; in order not to lose wholesome roots, one practices heedfulness; unmoved, sincere, and not sinking in one's undertakings, one is able to ultimately ascend to the higher dharmas; seeking the provisions of merit without satisfaction, seeking the provisions of wisdom never abandoning themâ€”this is the correct path of the bodhisattva.
Moreover, good man!

The path of the bodhisattva refers to the four dhyÄnas, the four immeasurable minds, the four formless concentrations, the five supernatural powers, the three meritorious actions, the three trainings, the six objects of respect, the six recollections, the four means of conversion, the four establishments of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five strengths, the seven factors of enlightenment, the eightfold noble path, the three gates of liberation, the skillful means of knowing the aggregates, the skillful means of knowing the realms, the skillful means of knowing the sense bases, the skillful means of knowing the truths, and the skillful means of knowing dependent origination. This is called the path.
Bodhisattvas who attain accomplishment in this path of skillful means are all able to follow and enter the path of the six perfections.
The reason for this is that the bodhisattvas' path of the six perfections is not shared with all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
This path is praised by all buddhas and emerges from the mouths of the tathÄgatas.
Bodhisattvas who accomplish skillful means and are able to understand the true nature of all dharmas are able to abide in the supramundane path of the six perfections.
What is meant by abiding?
Good man!
If there are bodhisattvas who accomplish the wisdom and skillful means of spontaneity and seek bodhi, in order to truly awaken to the five aggregates
that are grasped, they seek bodhi. This bodhisattva knows that form is impermanent and
practices giving. He knows that form is suffering, knows that form is non-self, knows that form is dull, knows that form is

without wisdom, knows that form is like an illusion, knows that form is like the moon in water, knows that form is like a dream, knowsğŸ”½that form is like a shadow, knows that form is like an echo, knows that form is like a transformation,
Know that form is like a shadow, know that form is like an echo, know that form is like a whirling firebrand, know that form is without self
, know that form is without sentient beings, know that form is without life, know that form is without a person, know that form is without
a master, know that form is without a nourisher, know that form is empty, know that form is without characteristics, know that form is without aspirations
, know that form is without action, know that form is unborn, know that form is unarisen, know that form is unoriginated
, know that form is formless, know that form is tranquil, know that form is detached, know that form is endless,
know that form is unaccomplished, know that form is equal to space, know that form is of the nature of nirvana, and yet
practice giving.
When the bodhisattva practices giving in this way, he knows that form is also detached because giving is detached, and he knows that giving is also detached because form is detached;
because form and giving are detached, he knows that aspirations are also detached, and because aspirations are detached, he knows that form and giving are also detached;
Knowing that enlightenment is also free because form, giving, and vows are free, and knowing that all dharmas have the same nature as enlightenment because enlightenment is free.
Good sons!
This is the supramundane dÄna-pÄramitÄ of the bodhisattva. Feeling, perception, and volition are also like this. Knowing
that consciousness is impermanent, one should practice giving. Knowing that consciousness is suffering, knowing that consciousness is non-self, knowing that consciousness is dull,
knowing that consciousness is non-wisdom, knowing that consciousness is like an illusion, knowing that consciousness is like a mirage, knowing that
consciousness is like the moon in the water, knowing that consciousness is like a dream, knowing that consciousness is like a shadow, knowing that consciousness is like an echo, knowing that
consciousness is like a whirling fire wheel, knowing that consciousness is non-self, knowing that consciousness is devoid of sentient beings, knowing that

consciousness is devoid of life, knowing that consciousness is devoid of person, knowing that consciousness is devoid of owner, knowing that consciousness is devoid of nourisher, knowing that consciousness is
like emptiness, knowing that consciousness is signless, knowing that consciousness is wishless, knowing that consciousness is unconditioned, knowing thatğŸ”½consciousness is
Birth and cognition are non-arising, cognition is non-emerging, cognition is formless, cognition is tranquil,
cognition is detached, cognition is endless, cognition is non-accomplishing, cognition is equal to empty space, cognition is like the nature of nirvana, and yet one practices giving.
When the bodhisattva practices giving in this way, because giving is detached, cognition is also detached; because cognition is detached, giving is also detached.
Because cognition and giving are detached, vows are also detached; because vows are detached, cognition and giving are also detached.

Because cognition, giving, and vows are detached, one also knows that enlightenment is detached; because enlightenment is detached, cognition, giving, and vows are also detached, and one knows that all dharmas are the same as the nature of enlightenment.
Good man!
This is the bodhisattva's supramundane perfection of giving.
Furthermore, good man!

Bodhisattvas know that form is impermanent and yet maintain their precepts, and know that form is of the nature of nirvana and thus maintain their precepts. They know that feeling, perception, and formation are the same, and know that consciousness is impermanent and yet maintain their precepts, and know that consciousness is of the nature of nirvana and thus maintain their precepts.

Because the precepts are detached, they know that form is also detached, and because they know that the precepts are detached, they know that up to consciousness is also detached, and know that all dharmas are the same as the nature of enlightenment.
Good sons!
This is called the bodhisattvas' supramundane perfection of morality.
The perfections of patience, vigor, and meditation are also like this.
Knowing that form is impermanent, one practices wisdom, and knowing that form is of the nature of nirvana, one practices wisdom.
Knowing that feeling, perception, and formation are impermanent, one practices wisdom, and knowing that consciousness is of the nature of nirvana, one practices wisdom.
Because wisdom is equal, one knows that consciousness is equal, and because consciousness is equal, one knows that wisdom is equal;
Because wisdom and consciousness are equal, one knows the equality of vows. Because of the equality of vows, one knows the equality of wisdom and consciousness.

Knowing the equality of wisdom, consciousness, and vows, one knows the equality of enlightenment. Because of the equality of enlightenment, one knows the equality of wisdom, consciousness, and vows. One then knows that all dharmas are of the same nature as enlightenment.
Good man!

This is the supramundane perfection of wisdom. This is the supramundane path of perfection for bodhisattvas. It can completely encompass all paths. One should know that all paths are included within it.
Why is it called supramundane?
Good man!

The five appropriated aggregates are called the mundane world. Bodhisattvas skillfully discriminate the five aggregates, contemplating their impermanence and so forth, up to knowing their nature is like nirvÄá¹‡a. They know that within this path there is no mundane world or mundane dharmas. They know that this path is undefiled, supramundane, and unattached. This is called supramundane.
Good man!
This is called the bodhisattva path.

Furthermore, the path refers to seeking all dharmas as they really are, discerning and selecting without seeing any dharmas, without duality or distinction in continuity and accumulation, and therefore it is called the path.
This path is without aversion or attachment, and because of the absence of aversion and attachment, it is called equality.
Because it is free from the contemplation and observation of other vehicles, it is called vast.ğŸ”½Because it is free from deceit, it is called upright.
Because it is free from crooked thoughts, it is called guileless.
Because it eliminates the hindrances, it is called unhindered.
Because it is free from the perceptions of desire, anger, and harmfulness, it is called dust-free.
Because it does not crave form, sound, smell, taste, or touch, it is called blissful.
Because it is free from demonic activities, it is called cool.
Because it is free from the thieves of afflictions, it is called fearless.
Because it can reach nirvana, it is called the way out.
Because it accomplishes tranquil concentration, it is called cool water.
Because of skillfully understanding wisdom, it is called constant illumination.
Because of skillfully cultivating loving-kindness, it is called cool and pleasant.
Because of not abandoning great compassion, it is called progressing without weariness.
Because of always practicing joy, it is called delight.
Because of accomplishing equanimity, it is called faultless.
Because of conforming with and embracing the Dharma, it is called greatly wealthy.

Because of accomplishing the power of the perfection of giving food, attaining the wisdom and eloquence of sarvajÃ±a, and being well-protected and upheld by the buddhas, it is called the Dharma practice that surpasses the four mÄras.
Because of not abandoning one's original vows, it is called progressing without obstruction.
Because of crossing over all the currents of afflictions, it is called unsurpassed.
Because there is no one in the world who can subdue it, it is called unopposed.
Good man!
This path accomplishes these and other immeasurable merits. All great beings ride this path and are able to come and go, teaching and transforming immeasurable beings. This is called adornment.
Not manifesting any afflictions while presently entering afflictions is its adornment.

Contemplating saá¹ƒsÄra without realizing the ultimate truth, reaching the gates of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, yet being able to teach and transform sentient beings who engage in views, signs, and vows is its adornment.
Manifesting entry into the nirvÄá¹‡a of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas without abandoning saá¹ƒsÄra is its adornment.
Manifesting rebirth in the various destinies without moving from the nature of dharmas, manifesting the teaching of all verbal teachings without moving from the absence of words, is its adornment.
Being able to manifest all buddha activities without abandoning bodhisattva practices is its adornment.
Good man!
This is the bodhisattvas' adornment of great vows, the adornment of the Great Vehicle, and the adornment of the path.

Because the bodhisattvas adorn themselves with the adornment of great vows, they are able to ride the Great Vehicle in accordance with the supramundane noble path, and for the sake of sentient beings who have not yet attained omniscience, they are able to perform buddha activities.
At that time, in the assembly there was a bodhisattva named RatnakÅ«á¹­a, who asked the bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha:
Good man!
Have you already cultivated this supramundane noble path?
Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha replied:
I have already cultivated it.
RatnakÅ«á¹­a said:
How did you cultivate it?
Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha replied:
As one attains the pure path, one cultivates in this way.
RatnakÅ«á¹­a asked:
What is the pure path?
Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha replied:
Good man!
Because the self is pure, the path is pure.
RatnakÅ«á¹­a asked:
What is the purity of the self?
Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha replied:
Like the purity of the world.
RatnakÅ«á¹­a asked:
What is the purity of the world?
Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha replied:
Good man!
The past limit of form is pure.
The reason is that the original limit of form is without coming.
The future limit of form is also pure.
The reason is that the future limit of form is without going. The present limit of form is also pure.
The reason is that present form is without abiding.
Good man!
This is called worldly purity.
Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness of the past are pure.
The reason is that the original limit of consciousness is without coming.
Consciousness of the future is also pure.
The reason is that the future limit of consciousness is without going.
Consciousness of the present is also pure.
The reason is that the present limit of consciousness is without abiding.
Good man!
This is called worldly purity.
Good man!
Because the world is pure in the world, the self is pure. Because the self is pure, this is called the purity of the Way.
Baode said:
Good man!
What does such a pure Way do?
AkÄÅ›agarbha replied:
One can create great wisdom-illumination. By the power of this wisdom-illumination, one can know the past and future limits of all dharmas.
RatnapÄtra asked again:
What is meant by the past and future limits of dharmas?
AkÄÅ›agarbha replied:
All dharmas are unborn at the past limit and unceasing at the future limit. This is called knowing the past and future limits.
RatnapÄtra asked again:
If one sees the past and future limits, what does one see?
AkÄÅ›agarbha replied:
One sees both as being apart.
RatnapÄtra asked again:
What is meant by both being apart?
AkÄÅ›agarbha replied:
Apart from annihilationism and eternalism.
Good man!
If one sees the arising of dharmas and becomes attached to dharmas, then this is the view of annihilationism and eternalism.
The reason is this: because there is birth, there is also cessation. Because there is birth and cessation, there are views of annihilation and permanence.

If one does not see dharmas arising from self-nature or other-nature, then one sees dependent origination. If one sees dependent origination, then one sees the Dharma. If one sees the Dharma, then one sees the TathÄgata. If one sees the TathÄgata, then one sees suchness. If one sees suchness, then one does not dwell in annihilation nor grasp at permanence. If one is neither permanent nor annihilated, then there is no arising and no cessation.
RatnakÅ«á¹­a asked again:
Good man!
If there is no arising and no cessation, how can there be names and numbers?
Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha replied:
It is only because of provisional verbal expression that there are dharmas with names.
Good man!

Just as because there is space, there are distinctions in form called blue, yellow, red, white, purple, crystal, and lapis lazuli colors, coarse form, fine form, long form, short form, square form, and round form, and space is not tainted by such dharmas.
However, the nature of all forms is also empty. All dharmas are also like this, the same as the nature of space, but only given names and numbers through verbal expression.

That is to say, good dharmas and bad dharmas, worldly dharmas and supramundane dharmas, dharmas to be done and dharmas not to be done, contaminated dharmas and uncontaminated dharmas, conditioned dharmas and unconditioned dharmas, but bodhisattvas also do not perform any non-meritorious actions. The meritorious actions they perform are all seen as deceptive, not true, and not solid.

This bodhisattva knows that all practices are not practices, and equally abandons all characteristics. Because of the power of accomplishing prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, he turns towards enlightenment but also does not see enlightenment as having increase or decrease. He does not seek enlightenment within form, nor does he seek enlightenment within feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness. Because the bodhisattva has no seeking, he abides in the pure precepts, cultivates the gate of liberation of the practice of non-expectation, and fulfills all vows.

He knows that the nature of birth and death is the same as the nature of nirvÄá¹‡a. Although he enters ultimate nirvÄá¹‡a, in order to eliminate the false and inverted thoughts of sentient beings, he practices the bodhisattva practices, and there is also no practice that can be practiced.
Good man!
In this way, the bodhisattva enters nirvÄá¹‡a and practices the bodhisattva practices.
Good man!ğŸ”½Anything that is done is birth and death, and nothing that is done is called nirvÄá¹‡a.
The practice of the bodhisattva is non-action, therefore the bodhisattva is called one who enters nirvÄá¹‡a and practices the bodhisattva practices.
Good man!
Those who have defilements, attachments, abodes, conceptual thoughts, and arguments, and grasp at characteristics, are called those in saá¹ƒsÄra.
Those who are free from defilements, attachments, abodes, conceptual thoughts, and arguments, and do not grasp at characteristics, are called those in nirvÄá¹‡a.

Bodhisattvas cultivate the practice of not having attachments, abodes, conceptual thoughts, and arguments, and grasp at characteristics, and carry out the bodhisattva practice. This is called the bodhisattva entering nirvÄá¹‡a and carrying out the bodhisattva practice.
When this Dharma was being spoken, five hundred bodhisattvas attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
At that time, the World-Honored One praised Bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Virtuous man!
You have eloquently spoken the nature of dharmas and the true and unchanging bodhisattva practice.
Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
This is the swiftness of the TathÄgata.
Why is it so?
It is because of the World-Honored One's wisdom-illumination that we have attained this eloquence.
World-Honored One!
It is like the sunlight illuminating JambudvÄ«pa. Due to the power of the sun's majestic virtue, those with eyes can see forms and carry out various activities.
The great wisdom power of the TathÄgata illuminates all sentient beings and worlds in the same way.
The true nature of all dharmas is inexpressible. The nature of all expressions is equal to space. Therefore, all dharmas cannot be counted.

Any counted dharmas have limits. Any limited dharmas are conditioned. Any conditioned dharmas can be known, can be eliminated, and can be cultivated. Any knowable, eliminable, and cultivable dharmas have attainment, have realization, and have names and counted dharmas.

Contemplating, calculating, and discriminating, one does not see any dharma that can be known, can be eliminated, can be cultivated, can be realized, or can be attained. Therefore, there is no attainment.
The reason for this is that all dharmas are unborn.

One who is able to see all dharmas in this way will not give rise to attachment to any dharmas. Because of being without attachment, there is no grasping. Because of being without grasping, there is no receiving and no taking.
What is meant by no receiving and no taking?
It means that whether form is permanent or impermanent, there is no receiving and no taking;
whether feeling, perception, mental formations, or consciousness are permanent or impermanent, there is no receiving and no taking.
Whether form is suffering or happiness, whether it has a self or is without a self, whether it is pure or impure, there is no receiving and no taking;
whether feeling, perception, mental formations, or consciousness are suffering or happiness, whether they have a self or are without a self, there is no receiving and no taking.
Whether form is empty or not empty, there is no receiving and no taking;
whether feeling, perception, mental formations, or consciousness are empty or not empty, there is no receiving and no taking.
Whether form is apart from or not apart from, there is no receiving and no taking;
whether feeling, perception, mental formations, or consciousness are apart from or not apart from, there is no receiving and no taking.
Because bodhisattvas have no grasping and no attachment, they attain the samÄdhi of non-grasping of all dharmas.

Having entered this samÄdhi, the buddhas, the world-honored ones, bestow the prophecy with the unsurpassed mind-to-mind transmission. Although this bodhisattva enters nirvÄá¹‡a, he sees that all sentient beings ultimately share the nature of nirvÄá¹‡a. In order to teach and transform sentient beings, he does not abandon the great vow adornments and the great compassion of the bodhisattvas.
How does a bodhisattva enter nirvÄá¹‡a and yet practice the bodhisattva path?
Good man!
Anything that is done is called birth and death.
Anything that is not done is called nirvÄá¹‡a.

The bodhisattva, with right wisdom, sees that all practices are free from characteristics. Because the bodhisattva clearly sees with the eye of Dharma-illumination, he is able to expound the illumination of the TathÄgata's wisdom.
At that time,
the bodhisattva Ratnaprabha asked the bodhisattva Ä€kÄÅ›agarbha, saying,
Good man!
Why do you conceal your own wisdom and say that it is all the power of the TathÄgata?
AkÄÅ›agarbha replied to RatnÄká¹£a, saying:
Good man!
Has the TathÄgata not spoken of concealing the good and revealing the bad?
Good man!
I will ask you in return, answer me as you will.
Good man!
What do you think?
If there were no Anavatapta Dragon King, could the great lake Anavatapta give rise to the four rivers to allow sentient beings to enjoy and make use of them?
RatnÄká¹£a replied, saying:
No, it could not.
AkÄÅ›agarbha said:
Good man!
If there were no TathÄgata, there would be no precepts and Dharma, and bodhisattvas would have no way to attain the great ocean of wisdom, nor would they be able to benefit all sentient beings.
Because the TathÄgata appears in the world, there are precepts and Dharma, and bodhisattvas can attain the great ocean of wisdom and also liberate and transform all sentient beings.
Good man!
Therefore, you should know that all the eloquent explanations obtained by bodhisattvas, which can benefit sentient beings, are the spiritual power of the TathÄgata.
